The Greens have a comprehensive plan to clean up politics and stop politicians writing policies for the highest bidder.  We will:

The Greens Banning Dirty Donations Bill to ban donations from gambling, mining & other sectors is already before the Senate, ready to be voted on - but only if Lib/Lab turn their back on the tens of millions in donations from the gambling industry filling their re-election chests

Weak political donations laws mean that not only is it completely legal for the govt to accept donations from industries that benefit from weak govt regulations, but that we don’t even know where more than a third of those donations come from. This is a stain on our democracy.
Donations open doors to Minister’s offices, giving privileged access to industries profiting at the expense of the Australian public.

The Greens have been pushing for this for a decade in federal parliament but the big parties won’t bite the hand that feeds them. Australians are the world's biggest losers to gambling, while the Liberal, Labor and National parties have hit the donations jackpot.

It’s time to ban political donations from the gambling industry. They've bought policy outcomes that reap them profits and increase misery for so many for so long.

Our bill passed the Senate more than two years ago - the PM just needs to bring it on for debate in the House and the Australian people could have a federal anti-corruption body in place by Christmas. There’s no more time to waste. #auspol

Our bill would establish a strong, independent, effective body that allows for public hearings, retrospectivity and the ability to investigate anonymous tip-offs, balanced with appropriate safeguards and privacy provisions. #auspol

Parliament doesn’t need to keep waiting for the long-delayed and pathetically weak Morrison model - because the Senate has already passed the Greens’ National Integrity Bill, which got top marks last week from the Centre for Public Integrity in a comparison of models. #auspol

Morrison’s ICAC proposal is a fraud. Many of the misconduct scandals involving current and former Government MPs would not be caught by his toothless model. It wouldn’t hold public hearings nor be able to initiate investigations without a referral from the government. #auspol

This is the dodgiest government in Australian history. If we had an effective federal anti-corruption body more than half of the Morrison Cabinet would be facing serious questions about their integrity. #auspol

The Govt has already twice blocked the bill from even being debated and voted on in the House but the Greens have been pushing for a federal corruption watchdog for 11 years now and we won’t stop despite this government using every excuse in the book to block and delay. #auspol

Next week in parliament I will move a concurrence motion which, if passed in the Senate, would force the House to vote on whether to debate my National Integrity Commission Bill, which passed the Senate two years ago. #auspol

An evidence based, properly funded, comprehensive National Plan is crucial to stopping violence against women. But it feels like the Morrison Gov just wants a showpiece Summit and a National Plan for Trying to Win Back Women Voters. Once again, they underestimate our intelligence

Bless the experts at the #WomensSafetySummit for so patiently saying the same things they've said so many time before. If Govt had been listening, they’d already know most of this. Women need more than a performative talkfest to try to make the PM look better, they need action!

I wrote about the government's underwhelming Respect@Work bill for @Refinery29AU today 👇
https://t.co/nfpYWyi6Rk
#WomensSafetySummit

Kate Jenkins: We need to make change. We owe it to all the women who marched and who’ve spoken out, but also those who haven’t been able to speak out, who continue to live with violence. #WomensSafetySummit

Mary Wooldridge:  Persistent group of loud voices that believe women make up or exaggerate allegations, despite evidence to the contrary.  We NEED real leadership to shift those attitudes and behaviours. #WomensSafetySummit

Kate Jenkins:  Insecure work can discourage people from approaching their workplace about abuse.  We need more resources for external supports like 1800 RESPECT and Working Women’s Centres as places for workers to seek advice. #WomensSafetySummit
Natalie Walker:  Survivors’ experiences MUST be centred in workplace harassment reforms. #WomensSafetySummit
Kate Jenkins:  A positive duty in the Sex Discrimination Act to be central to the cultural change she wanted the Respect@Work report to activate. #WomensSafetySummit

Kate Jenkins:  Last week was not the last word.  The Respect@Work recommendations that didn’t get implemented are not off the table. I and many others will continue to advocate for a positive duty. #WomensSafetySummit

Sian Lewis – getting bystanders to step up is critical to creating a more supportive workplace. Positive duties, supported by practical resources, are key to giving bystanders the confidence and tools they need to step up. #WomensSafetySummit

WGEA – Respect@Work report makes clear that we need meaningful data – company sexual harassment policies must be implemented and WORK. Review of WGEA Act is an important opportunity to improve data collection and identify resources needed to effect change. #WomensSafetySummit

Watching Respect@Work session of the #WomensSafetySummit. Mary Wooldridge, WGEA, said, “We need a culture than engages within the complexity of sexual harassment, rather than the reputation protection system we currently have”. Pos. duties are key to changing workplace culture.

We are going through this year's data drop of political donations. Here are some of the things we have found so far 👇
Companies currently vying for govt contracts or funding shouldn’t be able to influence the outcome through donations, and the Greens bill will help stop this.
Last year’s donations data also revealed that Adani had donated immediately prior to and following the Minister’s decision to approve its water management plan under federal environmental laws.
E.g the Walker Corporation, who donated while their environmental application to develop Toondah Harbour was being considered.

Recent history is littered with examples of government contracts being awarded to organisations who have made political donations and developers who have made donations while an application for environmental approval was still being considered.

Surely not even the big parties could stand in the way of such a common sense reform, that would begin the process of cleaning up politics and removing the influence of big money from decision making!
This change would stop the reality and the perception of bribery, where political donations occur and then environmental approvals or government contracts are awarded.

Our bill will stop companies who are seeking approval or applying for government tenders or contracts from being allowed to make a political donation while their application is on foot, or six months on either side of it.

But the big political parties won't turn off the tap that funds their re-election campaigns.

So the Greens are now proposing a very modest donation reform which the big parties have no legitimate reason not to support

The Greens have worked for a decade to lower the disclosure threshold and make it in real time, to end donations from certain sectors and to cap donations to no more than $1,000 per year to get the influence of big money out of politics.
Donations data will show today how much the big parties are owned by their corporate donors. People are sick of big donors getting special treatment and policy favours - it's democracy for sale.
The Greens will today announce a bill to prevent companies from buying government grant and tender outcomes through political donations.

Now more than ever the women of Australia need the gender pay gap closed, free childcare retained, valuing of the unpaid care work they disproportionately perform, and better pay for workers in feminised industries - many of whom have kept us safe during COVID.

It should be a standing agenda item for the National Cabinet to investigate the disproportionate and rising rate of women’s employment, value women’s paid and unpaid contribution to work and come up with a comprehensive plan for fixing structural inequalities.

Today I’ve called on the Morrison Government to place women's unemployment permanently on the agenda at National Cabinet meetings and to restore the Women’s Budget Impact statement, following yesterday’s record rise in unemployment for women.
The gender inequalities in the Australian jobs market have been turbo-charged by the COVID crisis and the Government’s lack of specific focus on supporting women to remain in employment.
